name: Bangkok
intro_vibe: The City of Angels: Where golden temples meet neon-lit chaos and street food reigns supreme.

general_info.description: Bangkok is the capital and most populous city of Thailand. A vibrant metropolis that never sleeps, Bangkok offers a sensory overload of ornate temples, bustling markets, world-class street food, and a nightlife that ranges from rooftop bars to raucous nightclubs. The city seamlessly blends ancient tradition with modern development, creating a uniquely chaotic yet captivating experience.

weather_breakdown.name: September
weather_breakdown.clothing: Mix of sun and rain gear

etiquette_tips: Respect the Monarchy: Never disrespect the King or Royal Family. It's illegal and deeply offensive. Stand for the royal anthem in cinemas.
Don't Touch Heads: The head is sacred in Thai culture. Never touch anyone's head, including children.
Remove Shoes: Take off shoes before entering temples, homes, and some shops. Look for shoes outside as a signal.
Dress Modestly at Temples: Cover shoulders and knees. Avoid shorts, tank tops, and revealing clothing at sacred sites.
Wai Greeting: Press palms together in a prayer-like gesture and bow slightly. Don't wai service workers or children.
Buddha Images Are Sacred: Never climb on Buddha statues or pose disrespectfully. It can result in arrest.
Keep Cool: Thais value composure (jai yen). Raising your voice or showing anger makes you lose face.

essential_phrases.local: เท่าไหร่ (Tao rai)

neighborhoods.name: Khao San Road
neighborhoods.description: The legendary backpacker street. Cheap hostels, street food, bucket cocktails, and travelers from every corner of the globe. Chaotic and touristy but essential Bangkok.

neighborhoods.name: Sukhumvit
neighborhoods.description: Bangkok's main expat and tourist district. High-end malls, rooftop bars, international restaurants, and red-light areas. Ultra-modern and connected by BTS Skytrain.

neighborhoods.name: Rattanakosin (Old City)
neighborhoods.description: The heart of royal Bangkok. Grand Palace, Wat Pho, and Wat Arun are all here. Crowded with tourists but essential for temple hopping and history.

neighborhoods.name: Chinatown (Yaowarat)
neighborhoods.description: Neon-lit chaos of gold shops, street food stalls, and traditional Chinese medicine stores. The best street food in Bangkok is found here, especially at night.

logistics.title: Getting Around
logistics.summary: BTS Skytrain and MRT Metro are clean, modern, and air-conditioned. Use them.
details: BTS Skytrain: Elevated train covering central areas (Sukhumvit, Siam, Silom). Buy a Rabbit Card for easy tapping.
MRT Metro: Underground lines connecting key areas. Separate ticketing from BTS.
Taxis: Abundant and cheap, but demand the meter ('meter na krap/ka'). Avoid taxis near tourist spots.
Tuk-Tuks: Iconic but overpriced. Agree on price before getting in. Only take for short trips or the experience.
Grab: Southeast Asia's Uber. Safer and more reliable than taxis. Widely used.
Boats: Chao Phraya Express Boat is scenic and fast for riverside sights. Orange flag boats are best for tourists.

logistics.title: Scams to Avoid
logistics.summary: Bangkok has friendly people, but tourist scams are common. Stay alert.
details: Tuk-Tuk Gem Scam: Driver offers cheap tour and takes you to a gem shop. They get commission, you get overpriced stones.
Temple Closed Scam: Friendly stranger says the temple is closed and offers to take you to another attraction (which is a scam).
Taxi Meter Scam: Taxi refuses to use the meter or claims it's broken. Insist on the meter or get out.
Jet Ski Scam: Rental operators claim you damaged the jet ski and demand thousands of baht. Avoid jet ski rentals.
Ping Pong Show: Overpriced drinks and entrance fees. You'll be hit with a massive bill. Stay away from touts.

logistics.title: Safety Basics
logistics.summary: Bangkok is generally safe, but use common sense in crowded areas.
details: Pickpockets: Active in crowded areas like Chatuchak Market and Khao San Road. Keep valuables secure.
Traffic: Bangkok traffic is insane. Use crosswalks, pedestrian bridges, and be cautious crossing streets.
Street Food: Eat where locals eat. Look for busy stalls with high turnover. Avoid lukewarm or old food.
Mosquitoes: Dengue fever is a risk. Use repellent, especially during rainy season. Cover up at dusk.
Emergency Number: 191 for police, 1669 for ambulance.

logistics.title: Apps to Download
logistics.summary: These apps will make Bangkok navigation seamless.
details: Grab: Essential for taxis and food delivery. Safer than street taxis.
Google Maps: Works well for BTS, MRT, and walking directions.
Wongnai: Thai Yelp for finding restaurants and reviews (in Thai but translates well).
Klook: Book tours, attractions, and skip-the-line tickets at discounts.
XE Currency: Live exchange rates. Useful for haggling at markets.

must_eat.description: Thailand's most famous dish: stir-fried rice noodles with shrimp or chicken, eggs, peanuts, bean sprouts, and tamarind sauce. Street cart versions are often better than restaurant ones.
Iconic hot and sour soup with shrimp, lemongrass, galangal, kaffir lime leaves, and chili. Intensely aromatic and flavorful. A must-try for soup lovers.
Spicy, sour, sweet, and crunchy salad made from shredded green papaya, tomatoes, peanuts, dried shrimp, and chili. Order 'mai phet' (not spicy) if you can't handle heat.

must_eat.name_local: ข้าวเหนียวมะม่วง
must_eat.description: Sweet sticky rice with ripe mango slices and coconut cream. Best during mango season (March-June). Simple but heavenly. A perfect dessert.
Thai-style fried rice with egg, onions, tomatoes, and your choice of protein. Often served with cucumber and lime. Simple, satisfying, and everywhere.

must_eat.name_local: แกงมัสมั่น
must_eat.description: Rich, mild curry with Persian and Indian influences. Made with beef or chicken, potatoes, peanuts, and coconut milk. Less spicy, more sweet and savory.

items.name_local: พระบรมมหาราชวัง
items.description: The most iconic landmark in Bangkok. Former royal residence with stunning architecture and Wat Phra Kaew (Temple of the Emerald Buddha). Strict dress code enforced.

items.name_local: วัดอรุณราชวราราม
items.description: Stunning riverside temple with a towering spire covered in colorful porcelain. Best viewed at sunset. Climb the steep stairs for river views.
Home to the massive 46-meter-long reclining Buddha covered in gold leaf. Also the birthplace of traditional Thai massage. Peaceful and beautiful.

items.name_local: ตลาดนัดจตุจักร
items.description: One of the world's largest weekend markets with over 15,000 stalls. Everything from clothing to antiques to pets. Overwhelmingly huge. Go early.

items.name_local: ตลาดน้ำดำเนินสะดวก
items.description: The most famous floating market near Bangkok. Vendors sell food and souvenirs from boats. Touristy but iconic. Go early (7am) to avoid crowds.

items.name_local: เอเชียทีค เดอะ ริเวอร์ฟร้อนท์
items.description: Upscale night market and mall complex along the Chao Phraya River. Restaurants, shops, and a giant Ferris wheel. More polished than street markets.

items.name_local: บาร์บนดาดฟ้า
items.description: Bangkok is famous for rooftop bars with stunning skyline views. Vertigo, Sky Bar at Lebua, and Octave are among the best. Dress code applies.

items.name_local: เอ็มบีเค เซ็นเตอร์
items.description: Massive shopping mall with electronics, clothing, souvenirs, and a food court. Great for cheap shopping and people-watching. Can be overwhelming.

affiliate_products.title: Portable Neck Fan
affiliate_products.reason: Bangkok heat and humidity are brutal. A hands-free neck fan keeps you cool while sightseeing and doesn't drain your phone battery.

affiliate_products.title: Mosquito Repellent Spray
affiliate_products.reason: Dengue fever is a real risk in Bangkok, especially during rainy season. DEET-based repellent is essential for temples and outdoor markets.

affiliate_products.title: Travel Money Belt
affiliate_products.reason: Pickpockets are active in crowded markets and tourist areas. A hidden money belt keeps your cash and passport secure under your clothes.
